Award.AwardTitle: RUI/Collaborative Research: Evaluating the Influence of Crustal Deformation on Episodic Magmatism: Southern Coast Mountains Batholith, British Columbia
Award.AbstractNarration: This project will evaluate processes responsible for the non-steady-state growth of continental crust in Cordilleran-type magmatic arcs. These batholiths develop as a result of subduction of oceanic lithosphere at convergent margins, but the processes that control the tempo of magma production are unclear; even in arcs where subduction is continuous, magmatism is strongly episodic (e.g. Sierra Nevada batholith, Peninsular Ranges batholith, Central Andes). Short periods (10-15 million years) of intense magmatism or 'flare-ups' may generate as much as 90% of total batholithic volumes, with little magmatism occurring during intervening lulls. Geochemical and isotopic signatures indicate that magmas produced during flare-ups incorporate more upper plate material than magmas formed during lulls. This pattern raises the question of whether continental growth by magmatic addition is controlled primarily by the behavior of the subducting oceanic plate or by the tectonics of the continental lithosphere at the plate margin. We are investigating this question through an integrated geologic, geochronological and geochemical study of the southern Coast Mountains Batholith in British Columbia. This project directly addresses a basic question in earth science: how do continents grow? In addition to the research goals of this project, this endeavor is enhancing the scientific education and training of students at four academic institutions recognized for the diversity of their student populations. Engagement of students in fieldwork, laboratory analysis, data interpretation and presentation of results are providing them with insights into all aspects of the science process and career options, and increase retention in STEM fields. Samples and datasets generated as a result of this project are being used to design problem sets and interpretive exercises for classes taught by the investigators. Data generated during this the course of this project is being added to NSF-funded databases, such as NAVDAT, for access by the larger community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
INTRODUCTION: Continental magmatic arcs develop at convergent plate boundaries, where the subduction of one plate beneath another produces large volumes of igneous rock. Understanding the timescales and processes governing the growth of these arcs is important because they are interpreted to be the places where continental crust is produced and recycled over Earth history. Large-scale studies of various continental arcs have revealed that the rates at which igneous volumes are produced is highly variable over time and space and that arc growth is episodic. This proposal focused on one of the largest exposed continental arcs on Earth – the Coast Mountains batholith of British Columbia. Episodic behavior had already been documented in one segment of the Coast Mountains batholith. In this work, a separate segment of the arc, with a different deformation history, was investigated in order to evaluate the influence of deformation on the timing of episodic magmatism. The main question being asked was: does deformation (e.g. compression, faulting, thickening of the crust) drive magmatic events in continental arcs?

Our specific objectives were to: 1) determine the timing of high magma addition rate (MAR) episodes, if present; 2) determine the timing of crustal deformation (when were faults active?); 3) determine the timing of metamorphism of the rocks into which the batholith is developed; 4) determine the geochemistry of the igneous rocks that make up the batholith.

NEW FINDINGS / INTELLECTUAL MERIT: The California State University, Northridge (CSUN) group focused on objectives (1) determining the timing of high MAR episodes, and (4) determining the geochemistry of the batholithic rocks. The main goal of the proposed work was to evaluate the extent to which deformation within the continental arc controlled the episodic nature of magmatism. Therefore, documenting the episodic behavior of arc magmatism in the southern part of the batholith and determining the timing of high MAR episodes there was of primary importance to the project. To that end, PIs and students from all involved institutions participated in the mapping and field collection of nearly 100 new batholithic samples. Crystallization ages (U-Pb in zircon), which effectively record when magmas were produced, were determined for 87 of those samples.

Analysis of these new ages indicates that magmatism is highly episodic in the southern batholith, with high MAR events occurring at 161-148 Ma, 114-102 Ma, 85-70 Ma and 61-48 Ma. Comparison with >300 existing ages for other segments of the batholith further revealed that the timing of high MAR events was highly variable along the length of the arc, even at relatively small (<150 km) spatial scales. We interpret this as indicating an upper plate control on the tempo of magmatic episodicity. Spatial analysis of the age data shows that although the tempo of magmatism is variable along strike of the arc, inboard arc migration rates and uniform, and similar to migration rates reported from other parts of the North American Cordillera. This suggests that trench-ward arc migration may be an intrinsic, self-regulating continental arc process, independent of whatever controls the timing of magmatic events.

The overall stated goal of this project is to determine what process(es) controls the episodic behavior of magmatism in this, and other, continental arcs. One model that is tested hypothesizes that compressional deformation in the upper plate leads to crustal thickening and the involvement of upper crustal rocks in melting, which could trigger high MAR events. To evaluate that model, our group looked for geochemical evidence of crustal involvement in magmas produced during high MAR events. Our results are somewhat ambiguous, but some geochemical and isotopic indicators suggest crustal thickening and a greater enhanced contribution from crustal sources during high MAR events. This is compatible with the conclusion from the age patterns that the upper plate exerts small-scale, primary control on the tempo of magmatism in arcs.

BROADER IMPACTS: This project supported theses by MS student Emily Homan, and BS student Christine Truong, both of whom graduated from CSUN in 2017 and are now employed by a geotechnical consulting firms in southern California. Research focused on zircon age dating and geochemical analysis at CSUN also supported undergraduate theses by Occidental College students Charles Chisom, Marshall Trautman and Kyle Oye. All of these students received extensive training while doing field work in British Columbia, as well as laboratory training performing mineral separations, preparing grain mounts for laser ablation mass spectrometric analysis and collecting in situ U-Pb and whole rock geochemical analyses. All CSUN and Occidental College students involved presented findings at regional and / or national meetings of the Geological Society of America. A manuscript with zircon and titanite age data has recently been submitted to a peer-reviewed geoscience journal, with Homan, Chisom and Trautman as co-authors.
